bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Atcheson Laughlin Hench, March 16, 1948

div1.p: Philip Hench discusses what day would be best for him to speak at the Albemarle County Historical Society meeting. He would like to work it in before his session at the International Congress on Tropical Medicine in Washington, but will accept any invitation with which Atcheson Hench is involved.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Atcheson Laughlin Hench, March 16, 1948
div1.opener:
March 16, 1948
Dr. A. L. Hench
East Jefferson Street
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Atch:
div1.p:
Mary and I had a marvelous time in Cuba and arrived home yester-
day morning. In unpacking my bags, I found again your nice birthday note
and reread it. To my dismay, I found that I did not answer the last para-
graph about the possible invitation of the Albemarle County Historical
Society. We left Palm Beach for Cuba the day after your letter arrived,
hence this matter slipped my mind.

Now, here's the dope. I am giving “the principal oration”on the
evening of Wednesday, May 12, in Washington, before the International Congress
on Tropical Medicine, the evening session being given over to a memorial for
Walter Reed as a preliminary of the unveiling of his bust in New York on May
20 in the Hall of Fame. My talk on May 12 will be only 30 minutes. They
have asked me to set up an exhibit on Walter Reed and I am planning to get
back my material now at the University and put it up at Washington and then
bring it back here. I had planned to ask the University to send the material
from Charlottesville to Washington and I had planned to arrive in Washington
probably Tuesday, the 11th. Now, on what days of the week does the Historical
Society have its meetings? Would Monday, May 10th, be agreeable? If so, I
could come straight to Charlottesville, speak that night, pick up my material,
go to Washington the 11th and set up the little exhibit and then speak on the
12th.

If Monday night, the 10th, is not agreeable, I suppose I could come
down for Thursday night, the 13th, but as you can see, from the standpoint of
my getting my material to Washington personally, it would be better for me to
be in Charlottesville before, rather than after, the Washington meeting on the
12th. Needless to say, I will accept any invitation with which you are concerned
in any way, if I possibly can. I will not be east in April but will, of course
attend Kahler's commencement at Mercersburg, Monday, June 7. I could come to
Charlottesville after that but would prefer to come in May. If either of these
dates is not suitable, I might come sometime in the fall, although I am going
to Europe in October and don't want to connect too many side-issues with that
trip.

In time I will send you a memorandum of my Cuban trip, most produc-
tive.

Kahler had a grand time with Margy at Swarthmore at the inter-
scholastic meet. Incidentally, Kahler again won first in diving against
17 prep schools and two weeks before, at Trenton, he won the Eastern Inter-
scholastic Diving Championship (first place in diving). Indeed, he has won
- 2 -
first place in diving in every meet this year except one, against the Navy
freshman; that meet I saw. Most unfortunately, his toe lightly touched the
board on one dive and the dive and its score was cancelled. Up to that point,
he had been ahead comfortably but that one dive made him take second place by
about two points. A pretty good record. Also, he has raised his scholastic
average and is now on the top honor roll, which is higher than the “First
Honor Roll” which latter he has been on for two years. His average is now
90. We just heard this morning that Al Snell's son is also accepted for
Lafayette and will probably room with Kahler. We are most pleased. Margy
mentioned the possibility of coming out this summer. She is welcome any
time and we certainly hope she can come. She and Kahler hit it off very well
apparently. He was delighted with her.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
